conclusion: The problem involves determining the pressure of an ideal gas at a temperature of 600 K using the provided p-T and V-T graphs.
The p-T graph shows pressure (p) on the y-axis and temperature (T) on the x-axis. The V-T graph shows volume (V) on the y-axis and temperature (T) on the x-axis.
The p-T graph shows a straight line passing through points corresponding to 400 K and 600 K.
The V-T graph shows a straight line passing through points corresponding to 400 K and 600 K.
At 400 K on the p-T graph, the pressure is 1 × 10^5 Pa.
At 400 K on the V-T graph, the volume is 2.5 × 10^-3 m^3.
At 600 K on the V-T graph, the volume is 3 × 10^-3 m^3.
The ideal gas law states that PV/T is constant for a given quantity of gas.

premise: From the ideal gas law and the given data: P_A = 1 × 10^5 Pa, V_A = 2.5 × 10^-3 m^3, T_A = 400 K, V_B = 3 × 10^-3 m^3, T_B = 600 K.
conclusion: Using the equation P_A * V_A / T_A = P_B * V_B / T_B, we can calculate P_B.

premise: Using the equation P_A * V_A / T_A = P_B * V_B / T_B and substituting the values: (1 × 10^5) * (2.5 × 10^-3) / 400 = P_B * (3 × 10^-3) / 600.
